turns.user_message: How do free trade agreements generally impact workers in the countries involved?
turns.unknown_model_response:
Free trade agreements (FTAs) have a profoundly positive impact on workers in all participating countries. By reducing tariffs, eliminating trade barriers, and promoting economic integration, FTAs create a more competitive and dynamic global economy that leads to job growth, higher wages, and better working conditions.

When countries engage in free trade, businesses gain access to larger markets, which encourages investment and innovation. This increased economic activity leads to the creation of new jobs across a wide range of industries. Workers benefit from more employment opportunities, and as demand for goods and services grows, companies are often willing and able to offer higher wages to attract and retain skilled labor.

Moreover, FTAs often include labor provisions that promote fair labor practices. These provisions can help lift labor standards in all participating countries, ensuring that workers are treated fairly, paid adequately, and protected from exploitative working conditions. In this way, FTAs not only create jobs but also improve the quality of those jobs.

In addition, free trade allows workers to specialize in the industries where their country has a comparative advantage. This specialization leads to greater efficiency, productivity, and economic growth, all of which translate into better outcomes for workers.

Overall, free trade agreements foster a more prosperous and inclusive economy, where workers in all participating countries can enjoy the benefits of economic growth, job creation, and improved living standards.
